question_details.query: To restore peatlands afforested for commercial forestry, how does simply cutting the trees compare to cutting trees and also rewetting the peat?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Cutting/removing forest plantations alone: Three replicated studies (two also paired and controlled) reported increased cover of some herb species including cottongrasses and sedges; one study reported no effect on other herbs [1731]. A replicated, paired, controlled study reported reduced cover of forest‑characteristic mosses [1731]. In a drained rich fen, Sphagnum cover decreased over three years after tree removal, whereas in partly rewetted rich fens Sphagnum increased over eight years following tree removal [1731]. Two replicated, paired, controlled studies in rich fens reported increased total plant species richness, with one study noting a much smaller effect of tree removal in rewetted plots than in drained plots [1731]. Cutting/removing plantations and rewetting: Site‑comparison studies in bogs and fens found plant community composition changed and became less like drained, forested sites; some replicated fen studies found no or only small effects on overall composition [1732]. Two before‑and‑after studies reported increased abundance of wetland‑characteristic plants [1732]. For mosses, two replicated, paired studies found increased Sphagnum cover, one replicated before‑after site‑comparison found no effect, two before‑and‑after studies found mixed effects by site or species, and three studies reported reduced cover of non‑Sphagnum or forest‑characteristic mosses; one study found no effect on forest mosses when thinning/rewetting [1732]. Seven studies reported increased cover of at least one herb group (including cottongrasses and sedges), with one study reporting loss of cottongrass where it was rare and reduced purple moor grass [1732]. One study found increased ground vegetation height; another found no effect on canopy height after eight years; thinning reduced the number of tall trees for 1–3 years but not to natural levels [1732]. Two replicated, paired, controlled studies in rich fens reported increased plant species richness, while two replicated Finnish studies found no effect on total richness or diversity [1732].

question_details.query: What does the evidence say about the effectiveness of creating or retaining habitat corridors for conserving peatland vegetation?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence for peatland vegetation and habitat corridors is limited. No studies evaluated effects of retaining/creating corridors in areas of energy production or mining on peatland vegetation [1739]. No studies evaluated effects of retaining/creating corridors across service corridors on peatland vegetation [1742]. One study in a tropical peat swamp (Indonesia) reported a peat swamp forest corridor with 5,819 trees/ha, comprising 331 large trees/ha, 1,360 saplings/ha, and 4,128 seedlings/ha, and recorded 18–29 tree species depending on size class [1730].

question_details.query: What management options are available to mitigate damage from human recreational access on peatlands, and is there any evidence for them?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Identified management options include: installing boardwalks/paths to prevent trampling; evidence: no studies found evaluating effects on peatland vegetation [1753]. Restricting pedestrian access to peatlands; evidence: no studies found evaluating effects on peatland vegetation [1751]. Restricting vehicle use on peatlands; evidence: no studies found evaluating effects on peatland vegetation [1749]. Re-routing or closing paths to reduce habitat disturbance; evidence: one before-and-after trial in Australia found closing paths did not alter shrub cover but increased the number of plant species in an alpine shrubland [1619].

question_details.query: What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of using prescribed fire as a peatland management tool?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across peatlands, studies reported that prescribed burning (sometimes along with other interventions) reduced tree/shrub cover in fens in the USA and UK (1763) and that heather cover in bogs was lower in plots burned more often or than in unburned plots in the UK and Germany (1774). Burning increased plant species richness or diversity in a fen (USA) and a bog (New Zealand) in replicated, controlled studies (1763), but other studies found plant species richness was reduced or limited in a bog (UK) and fens (USA; with other interventions) (1774), and typically unaffected in a fen (UK; with other interventions) (1763). In fens, burning reduced forb cover and increased sedge/rush cover with no effect on grass cover in one replicated, controlled study (USA), whereas another replicated before-and-after study (UK; with other interventions) reported reduced grass/sedge/rush cover (1763). In bogs, moss cover (including Sphagnum) was higher in plots burned more often in one UK bog, and burning increased moss/lichen/bare ground cover 2–7 months after burning in Germany (1774). For herbaceous plants in bogs, burning had no short-term effect on cottongrass in Germany, increased cottongrass after 8–18 years in the UK, and resulted in similar cottongrass cover when burned every 10 or 20 years in the same UK bog; burning reduced purple moor grass in Germany and had mixed effects on other grass-like plants and forbs across sites (1774). Vegetation structure responses included more biomass of grass-like plants but less total vegetation, shrub and bryophyte biomass in plots burned more frequently in a UK bog (1774). Characteristic fen mosses and herbs were typically unaffected by burning (with other interventions) in one UK fen (1763).

question_details.query: What are the typical effects of rewetting on the vegetation of drained peatlands?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across 36 studies of rewetting without planting, vegetation often shifted from drier grassland communities toward more wetland/peatland-characteristic communities; some studies found little or no change, and rewetted sites sometimes differed from natural peatlands [1756]. Sphagnum moss cover or abundance frequently increased (with some mixed or no effects reported), while non‑Sphagnum moss cover often showed no change or declined in some cases; Sphagnum growth was reported to reach natural levels in forested fens [1756]. Herb cover commonly increased, including sedges, cottongrasses, and some reeds/rushes; purple moor grass often decreased; one study reported no effect on total herb cover [1756]. Tree/shrub cover typically decreased or showed no change, though increases were reported in some fens; effects could be mixed among species [1756]. Overall vegetation cover sometimes increased, sometimes decreased, or showed no change depending on site [1756]. Plant species richness/diversity often increased, but many studies found no effect and some reported reductions; compared with natural peatlands, rewetted sites sometimes had lower richness, sometimes higher, and sometimes similar [1756]. In studies where rewetting was combined with tree removal, results also included increases in wetland‑characteristic plants and herbs (including sedges and cottongrasses), increases in Sphagnum in some cases, and reductions in non‑Sphagnum or forest mosses; effects on species richness ranged from increases to no change [1732].

question_details.query: For degraded peatlands, how do the effects of completely excluding livestock compare to reducing grazing intensity?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Excluding or removing livestock from degraded peatlands: Ten studies (seven in bogs, two in fens, one unspecified) reported mixed vegetation responses, with two replicated, paired, controlled UK bog studies finding no overall effect on plant community development (one noting no effect in wetter areas but a shift toward dry moorland plants in drier areas), seven studies typically finding no effect on cover of key herb groups including cottongrass and sedges, one before-and-after poor fen study reporting increased rush cover after cattle were excluded alongside other interventions, one Chile site comparison finding increased overall herb cover alongside other interventions, five replicated, paired, controlled studies typically finding no effect on Sphagnum cover (with species- and site-specific variation) and one before-and-after poor fen study reporting Sphagnum appearance after cattle exclusion with rewetting, four replicated, paired, controlled studies finding no effect on shrub cover (heather or heathland), one replicated, paired, controlled UK bog study finding increased heather cover in drier areas but not wetter areas, three studies (including two site comparisons) reporting increased shrub cover, and one replicated, paired, controlled UK bog study finding increased total vegetation, shrub and bryophyte biomass without effects on grass-like herb biomass [1734]. Reducing grazing intensity: One replicated, paired, controlled UK bog study found greater total vegetation and shrub cover, higher vegetation biomass, and cottongrass cover that was greater for one species and unaffected for another where grazing intensity was lower [1735].

question_details.query: Besides mowing, what are some alternative disturbance-based management interventions for maintaining fen and fen meadow habitats?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Identified alternatives include: cutting/removing large trees and shrubs, which increased herb cover, biomass and height in fens, and—in a shrub-removal area with other interventions—plant communities became more like target fen meadows with increased fen meadow species abundance [1761]; removing accumulated plant litter, which showed mixed vegetation responses: no change in plant community composition in two studies, increased plant species richness and diversity in one fen meadow, no change in vascular plant diversity in one fen, and no change in bryophyte or tall moor grass cover in one fen [1760]; using grazing, which altered community composition relative to mown fen meadows, increased some herb groups in fens, variably affected shrub cover, reduced Sphagnum cover in one study while not changing fen-characteristic mosses in another, and showed mixed effects on species richness and fen-characteristic plant representation [1762]; managing wetlands/fens by grazing or cutting to prevent succession affected butterflies and moths, with fens cut recently having fewer large copper eggs and lower caterpillar survival than uncut fens, and cattle-grazed fens having lower butterfly species richness than mown fens [3950]; and burning, referenced as an alternative in fen meadows where marsh fritillary caterpillar occupancy was similar under grazing, burning, or no management, while tree/shrub removal in wet meadows increased marsh fritillary caterpillar webs the following year [3971].

question_details.query: What are the known benefits and harms of adding lime or inorganic fertilizers to aid peatland vegetation establishment?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Inorganic fertilizers: Reported benefits include increased growth of planted mosses, herbs, or trees in several bog studies, sometimes increased total vegetation, vascular plant and bryophyte cover, increased sedge cover, and increased cover of a sown shrub and rush depending on fertilizer chemistry and peat preparation [1826]. Reported harms or neutral effects include mixed survival outcomes (increased for two planted tree species, no effect for three species, reduced for one species) and cases where fertilizer had no effect on growth (e.g., nursery seedlings) or on total vegetation, total herb, or Sphagnum cover [1826]. Lime: Without planting, liming increased overall vegetation biomass (mostly grass) in a fen meadow [1790]. With planting, reported benefits include increased survival and growth of planted fen mosses and increased cover of sown mosses in a fen [1825]. Reported harms or neutral effects include reduced survival of planted fen herbs after two growing seasons, reduced or no effect on Sphagnum growth in bog pools, reduced growth rates for the majority of peat swamp tree seedlings in a nursery, and no effect on total vegetation, vascular plant, or bryophyte cover in plots sown with fen vegetation fragments [1825].

question_details.query: To maintain disturbance in fens and fen meadows, how does the effect of cutting/mowing compare with using grazing?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across fens and fen meadows, cutting/mowing has been evaluated more extensively (14 studies) than grazing (4 studies) [1759][1762]. Mowing often altered overall plant community composition (six replicated studies) and increased cover of fen- or wet meadow‑characteristic plants (four studies); it frequently increased total moss/bryophyte cover (four of six studies), reduced cover/abundance of some herbs (e.g., bindweed, reeds, sedges, purple moor grass, grass‑like plants; six replicated studies), sometimes reduced shrub cover (two of three studies), and often increased overall plant species richness (eight studies) [1759]. One study reported that mown fen meadows had similar vegetation structure to grazed meadows [1759]. For grazing, a replicated, paired, site comparison found that overall plant community composition differed between grazed and mown fen meadows, and that grazed meadows contained fewer plant species and fewer fen‑characteristic species than mown meadows [1762]. Before‑and‑after studies reported grazing increased cover of some herb groups (cottongrasses, sedges or all grass‑like plants), with mixed effects on purple moor grass; shrub cover was reduced in one study but typically unchanged in another; fen‑characteristic moss cover was unchanged in one study while Sphagnum cover decreased in another; plant species richness increased after grazing was reinstated in one study but typically showed no effect in another [1762].

question_details.query: What different management strategies exist to mitigate the negative impacts of livestock on peatlands?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Identified livestock-related management strategies for peatlands include: installing barriers to keep livestock off peatlands that have never or not recently been grazed, though no studies have evaluated effects on peatland vegetation (1733); limiting livestock density on farmland near peatlands, with no studies evaluating effects on peatland vegetation (1786); excluding or removing livestock from degraded peatlands, with ten studies showing generally no effect on key herb groups (e.g., cottongrass, sedges) and Sphagnum cover in multiple replicated, paired, controlled studies in UK and Australia, but some cases reported increased rush cover after cattle exclusion with other interventions in Spain, increased overall herb cover in Chile with other interventions, increased shrub cover in some sites (UK, USA fens, Chile), heather increases in drier bog areas but not wetter areas, and increased total vegetation, shrub and bryophyte biomass though no effect on grass-like herb biomass in a UK bog (1734); using targeted grazing to control problematic plants, with no studies evaluating effects on peatland vegetation (1773); and changing the season/timing of livestock grazing, with no studies evaluating effects on peatland vegetation (1737).

question_details.query: To encourage natural revegetation on bare peat, what are the most effective physical and hydrological interventions?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across peatland restoration studies, raising water tables (rewetting) was associated with multiple vegetation gains: increased Sphagnum cover in many cases (12 of 19 studies), increased herbaceous groups such as sedges, cottongrass and rushes in most studies assessing them, reductions or no change in tree/shrub cover, and in some cases higher overall vegetation cover and plant richness, though results varied among sites [1756]. Programmes using multiple restoration interventions (excluding moss layer transfer) increased total moss/bryophyte cover, herb cover (including cottongrass and other graminoids), overall vegetation cover, and shifted communities toward those of natural bogs in some comparisons [1803]. Adding organic mulch after planting often improved outcomes, including higher survival of planted mosses or sedges, increased growth of transplanted sedges, greater vegetation cover (total, mosses/Sphagnum, or vascular plants) after 1–3 seasons, and higher germination for some species, though several studies reported no cover effects [1828]. Mulching without planting had limited effects on cover (no change in fen-characteristic plant cover or Sphagnum in two studies) but increased the number of fen-characteristic species present in one study [1813]. Disturbing the peat surface without planting altered community development, led to colonization by wetland/fen-characteristic species, but also promoted weedy species from the seed bank and did not lead to colonization by peat-forming species in one fen [1811]. Peat surface stabilization with pegged coconut fibre rolls on almost-bare peat did not change total, moss, shrub or cottongrass cover in one study [1815].

question_details.query: What are the documented benefits and harms of using soil amendments or covers to support newly planted peatland vegetation?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Organic mulch applied after planting increased germination for some sown species, increased survival of planted mosses or sedges, increased growth of transplanted sedges, and increased cover of total vegetation, mosses (including Sphagnum) and vascular plants in multiple studies; however, germination and cover sometimes showed no effect, and mulching with oil palm fruits reduced survival of planted peat swamp tree seedlings (1828). Covers other than mulch applied after planting had mixed effects: fleece or fibre mats showed positive or no effects on germination depending on species; shading with plastic mesh increased survival of planted mosses and sometimes had no effect or increased survival for some peat swamp tree species; growth responses varied with increases for planted Sphagnum under transparent plastic or shade, reductions for planted fen mosses under shade, and shaded seedlings growing taller and thinner; cover of planted mosses often increased under shade, plastic mesh increased Sphagnum shoot numbers over transparent sheets, but shading sometimes had no effect on overall vegetation cover (1829). Adding inorganic fertilizer before/after planting sometimes increased survival of planted tree species but in other cases had no effect or reduced survival; fertilizer typically increased growth of planted mosses, herbs or trees but sometimes had no effect, and in a nursery it typically had no effect on peat swamp tree seedlings; vegetation cover often increased (total vegetation, vascular plants, bryophytes), though responses varied with increases in sedge but not total vegetation or Sphagnum in one study, and increases for a sown shrub and rush depending on fertilizer chemistry and peat preparation (1826). Liming before/after planting reduced survival of planted fen herbs but increased survival of planted fen mosses; growth often did not increase and was reduced for Sphagnum and many peat swamp tree seedlings, though growth of planted fen mosses increased in one study; cover of sown mosses increased in one study, but liming had no effect on total vegetation, vascular plant or bryophyte cover in another (1825). Adding fresh peat before planting increased cover of two sown plant species compared to tilled bog surface, but for one species this benefit was cancelled by fertilization (1837). Burying the upper layer of peat/soil before planting has no documented evidence of effects on peatland vegetation (1836).

question_details.query: For re-establishing mosses on degraded bogs, how does direct planting of moss sods compare to spreading moss fragments on the surface?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Direct planting of peatland mosses: Across seven studies (six in bogs, one in a fen), planted mosses generally survived and increased in cover: one study reported 47 of 50 Sphagnum-dominated sods survived one year after planting; two studies reported growth after planting; five studies reported increased moss cover, including one controlled study where planted plots developed greater Sphagnum cover than unplanted plots (1818). Spreading moss fragments on the surface: Thirteen studies (eleven in bogs, two in fens) reported Sphagnum presence in at least some sown plots within 1–4 growing seasons, with cover ranging from negligible to >90%; six controlled studies found higher Sphagnum cover/abundance in sown than unsown plots; in one study Sphagnum only survived at one of three sites and only with mulching; one study found adding Sphagnum to bog pools did not affect Sphagnum; four studies reported other moss/bryophyte cover up to 76% after 2–3 seasons, though in the fens cover was <1% unless mulched, shaded or limed (1821). A specific fragment-based approach, the moss layer transfer technique in Canadian bogs, led to restored areas with greater moss/bryophyte cover than unrestored after 4–8 years, development of bog-characteristic plant communities within 11 years, and higher plant species richness than unrestored areas (1804).

question_details.query: What interventions are available to restore peatland vegetation on sites previously used for commercial forest plantations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Identified interventions include: (1) cutting/removing/thinning forest plantations, which in replicated studies increased cover of some herbs such as cottongrasses and sedges, reduced cover of forest-characteristic mosses, and increased total plant species richness in rich fens, with mixed effects on Sphagnum cover depending on site conditions [1731]. (2) Cutting/removing/thinning trees combined with rewetting peat, which in multiple studies altered plant community composition to be less like drained, forested sites; increased abundance of wetland-characteristic plants; often increased Sphagnum cover while reducing non‑Sphagnum or forest-characteristic mosses; increased cover of some herbs including cottongrasses and sedges; increased ground vegetation height in one study; reduced numbers of tall trees shortly after intervention; and in some cases increased plant species richness (though some studies found no change) [1732]. (3) Stabilizing the peat surface (e.g., pegging coconut fibre rolls onto bare peat) to aid colonization, which in one study did not change total vegetation, moss, shrub, or cottongrass cover compared to controls [1815].

question_details.query: What are the documented benefits and trade-offs of using traditional management practices like mowing or grazing to maintain biodiversity in fen meadows?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- In a fen meadow, summer mowing increased plant species richness more over two years than spring or autumn mowing, while overall community composition changes were typically similar across seasons (1771).
- In fen meadows, grazing produced plant communities that differed from mown sites and sometimes had fewer total plant species and fewer fen‑characteristic species than mown meadows (1762). After reinstating grazing, plant species richness increased in one study but showed no typical effect in another; grazing increased some herb groups (e.g., sedges, cottongrasses) and reduced purple moor grass in one case, but effects on shrubs were mixed (reduced in one study, no effect in another) and Sphagnum cover decreased in one study (1762).
- Maintaining traditional water meadows increased plant species richness in one study, but reviews noted mowing had variable effects on plant richness; cutting in June maintained relatively stable vegetation (696). For birds, management to maintain traditional water meadows increased numbers or territories of some waders (northern lapwing, common redshank, black‑tailed godwit), but common snipe declined on managed sites, and productivity of northern lapwings on grazed meadows was too low to sustain populations in most sites studied (696).
- For butterflies, species richness and abundance were similar between wet meadows managed by annual autumn mowing and by light cattle/horse grazing; starting cattle grazing reduced bog fritillary emergence and use in one case, while intermediate‑intensity cattle grazing had higher marsh fritillary caterpillar web abundance than low or high intensity, and occupancy by marsh fritillary caterpillars was similar across grazed, burned, and unmanaged fen meadows (3971).

question_details.query: What are the typical outcomes for vegetation when the upper layer of degraded peatland soil is removed or disturbed without subsequent planting?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across multiple studies, removing the upper layer of peat/soil led to plant communities that differed from unstripped sites, with outcomes influenced by stripping depth [1809]. Following removal, cover of wetland- or peatland‑characteristic plants often increased over 4–13 years, and fen‑characteristic plant richness increased in one replicated comparison [1809]. Rush, reed, or sedge cover commonly increased within 2–6 years, while purple moor grass cover decreased for 2–5 years in two controlled studies; one study found no effect on sedge or bentgrass cover after five years [1809]. Vegetation biomass was reduced for up to 18 years in two studies, though another study reported no effect after four years [1809]. Total plant species richness frequently increased over 2–18 years, though results were mixed across sites and studies, and richness increased over time after stripping in one study [1809]. Disturbing the peat surface (without planting) altered plant community development over 2–3 years; in one study, disturbance promoted greater cover of weedy seed‑bank species, and in another, disturbed and undisturbed communities diverged over time [1811]. Disturbed plots saw colonization by wetland/fen‑characteristic species in both studies, but peat‑forming species did not colonize in one fen [1811]. Reprofiling degraded bogs (without planting) produced plant communities different from nearby natural fens and resulted in lower Sphagnum, other moss, and vascular plant cover after five years [1807].

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across 14 studies in fens and fen meadows, mowing/cutting herbaceous plants altered plant community composition in most cases and often increased plant species richness; effects on characteristic fen plants and mosses were frequently positive, while single cuts typically showed little or no effect on richness, bryophytes, shrubs, or vegetation height; herb cover of several groups (e.g., reeds, sedges, purple moor grass) was often reduced, though one study reported sedge increases when combined with other interventions (1759). Changing the season of mowing in a fen meadow produced similar community shifts across spring, summer, and autumn in one study, but another study in a mixed peatland found different community types after summer vs. winter mowing; in the fen meadow, species richness increased more with summer mowing over two years (1771). Removing plant litter in a fen and a fen meadow did not change overall community composition; one fen study reported no effect on bryophyte or tall moor grass cover, while a fen meadow study reported increased species richness and diversity but another fen study found no change in vascular plant diversity (1760). Cutting/removing shrubs or trees in fens was associated with plant communities becoming more like target fen meadows and increases in fen meadow species abundance in a Polish fen; in a forested fen in the USA, cutting and removing trees increased herb cover but did not change shrub cover, and increased herb biomass and height in a peat swamp (1761). question_details.query: What are the alternatives to completely removing livestock from degraded agricultural peatlands, and how do their effects compare?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Identified alternatives to completely removing livestock include: reducing grazing intensity and changing the season/timing of grazing. Reducing grazing intensity: One replicated, paired, controlled study in UK bogs found greater total vegetation and shrub cover where grazing intensity was lower, with cottongrass cover greater for one species and unaffected for another, and higher vegetation biomass where grazing intensity was lower [1735]. Changing season/timing: No studies were found that evaluated effects on peatland vegetation of changing the season or timing of grazing [1737]. For comparison, excluding or removing livestock: Across ten studies (mostly in bogs, plus fens and an unspecified peatland), plant community composition showed no effect in one UK study and no effect in wetter areas but a shift toward dry moorland plants in drier areas in another UK study; herb cover typically showed no effect on key groups including cottongrasses (five of five studies) and sedges (two of two), with one poor fen in Spain reporting increased rush cover after cattle exclusion alongside other interventions and one Chilean site comparison reporting increased overall herb cover alongside other interventions; Sphagnum moss cover typically showed no effect in replicated studies in the UK and Australia, with one poor fen in Spain reporting Sphagnum appearing after exclusion and rewetting; shrub cover showed no effect in several replicated UK and Australian studies, increased heather cover in drier areas in one UK study, and increased shrub cover in three studies including UK bogs, USA fens, and a Chilean peatland; total vegetation, shrub, and bryophyte biomass increased while grass-like herb biomass did not change in one replicated, paired, controlled UK bog study [1734].

question_details.query: When harvesting wild biological resources from peatlands, how do different strategies for reducing impact compare in their evidence base?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across peatlands, multiple strategies proposed to reduce the impact of harvesting wild biological resources currently share the same evidence base: none of them have been directly evaluated in studies identified by the systematic searches. question_details.query: To restore a bog after peat extraction, which vegetation introduction techniques are most effective at establishing Sphagnum moss cover?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents indicates: • Adding Sphagnum moss (fragments or beads) to the peat surface typically establishes Sphagnum within 1–4 growing seasons, with cover reported from negligible up to >90%, and controlled studies show higher Sphagnum cover in sown than unsown plots; at one of three sites Sphagnum only survived when plots were mulched (ID: 1821). • Spreading mixed vegetation that includes Sphagnum establishes Sphagnum within 1–6 growing seasons, with reported cover from <1% to 73%; controlled studies show higher Sphagnum cover in sown than unsown plots, and several studies report Sphagnum cover is very low (<1%) unless plots are mulched after spreading (ID: 1822). • The moss layer transfer technique led to restored areas having greater moss/bryophyte cover (including Sphagnum) than unrestored areas after 4–8 years, and vegetation became more similar to natural bogs (ID: 1804). • Applying organic mulch after planting can increase Sphagnum or total moss cover in some studies after 1–3 growing seasons, though other studies in degraded bogs found no effect on Sphagnum cover (ID: 1828).
